definition: **noun / hi-fi engineering term.** A **porous bronze bearing** made by powder-metal sintering, self-lubricating with oil — widely used for quiet platter and tone-arm pivots. The manufacturing process compresses bronze powder under extreme pressure and heat, creating a porous metal matrix with microscopic voids that retain lubricating oil. This self-lubricating property makes sintered bronze ideal for turntable applications where consistent, low-friction rotation is critical for speed accuracy and rumble reduction. First adopted by high-fidelity turntable manufacturers in the 1950s, sintered bronze bearings became standard in quality decks from Thorens, Garrard, and Dual by the 1960s. The oil-impregnated structure provides years of maintenance-free operation, gradually releasing lubricant during use. Superior to solid bronze or steel bearings for audio applications due to their vibration-damping properties and silent operation — noise at the bearing translates directly to audible rumble. Modern audiophile turntables continue using sintered bronze for both main platter spindles and tonearm pivot points, though some ultra-high-end designs have shifted to ceramic or sapphire alternatives. Vintage turntables with dried-out sintered bearings can often be revived with proper re-oiling using light machine oil or specialized turntable bearing lubricants.
etymology: From metallurgical term 'sintering' (German 'sintern,' to fuse), the process of compacting metal powder through heat without full melting, combined with bronze alloy composition; adopted into audio engineering vocabulary during postwar hi-fi development.
